pros: All pros. Very good company to work for. Great coworkers. Everyone is friendly
cons: No cons. I regret leaving.

job_title: Emergency Room Nurse in Fresno, CA
pros: Great teamwork, decent pay, staff is pretty supportive
cons: Since madera community hospital closed, staffing is awful & a lot of floats/ travelers

review_title: Worked in a crazy chaotic ER until I was assaulted…
pros: You’ll always have hours, the grounds are nice and the food isn’t bad.
cons: Virtually no support after my assault, made it hard to return and then used COVID to “phase” me out. Full time is 7/12hr per 2 weeks Some really arrogant doctors. They focus on your appearance, tattoos and “extra” piercings which is anything past two holes in the ears, are big nonos which is stupid af. Catholic and it’s everywhere. Regular prayers over PA system.

pros: Saint Agnes makes a good effort to try and retain colleagues in a competitive market
cons: Job responsibility overload, no pay match

review_title: We need to wake up and Unionize
pros: Amazing teamwork, coworkers have your back.
cons: Pay is not worth the work load. We need better pay, possibly a UNION!

pros: Great pay and benefits. Some departments make it easy to get days off for Pto.

review_title: It’s a busy hospital, what can I say

cons: The electronic medical record system is terrible. Double charting within different systems that don’t talk to each other.

pros: Lots of experience and opportunity to grow your medical knowledge 2nd highest paying hospital in the valley Flexible work schedule
cons: Their retained staff have toxic attitudes and feelings of superiority, generally lacking regard for their fellow coworkers Security is never there when you need them to be Some equipment is outdated or broken Withdraw of incentives despite trinity health closing down Madera.. we have the same number of staff and now twice the patients. The hospital will make money but will not pay the overworked staff their portion.. puts patients at risks

pros: Nicer doctors and staff compare to other local hospitals. Well Organized hospital

cons: Pay isn't great, the ED and most departments are ran poorly. The entire place is poorly staffed, and people are over worked. Raises and bonuses are non-existent. Systems and equipment are very outdated.

review_title: Short staffed but the people are great

review_title: good place to work, some micromanagement
pros: good co workers, mission is faith-based
cons: low pay, high premiums, hard to advance

pros: Good pay and benefits. Hospital encourages professional development.
cons: Politics that are present in any health care setting.

pros: Other than Kaiser, generally the best pay and benefits in the Fresno area. At one time, it was a great place to work for, and it's still kept up nicely, they put a lot of money into appearance.
cons: The management style is very much of a you're either "in" or "out" of favor. Guess who gets cut first? They've been making cuts on top of cuts since about 2008. Staffing is very thin on the ground, though there still seems to be a lot of positions for supervisor, manager, lead, or whatever other name they have for Chief, rather than Native American. Suck-ups will do quite well for themselves there.If you're an informant for the boss, you're golden.

pros: Mostly nice co-workers, good food in the cafeteria.
cons: They treat their "staff" (non-nursing) very poorly.  Looong hours and low pay.  The benefits are not the greatest either.  The "C-Suite" group (both execs and staff) are very cliquish and full of themselves (with a few exceptions).  The CEO is very judgmental and very rude when you are on a 1:1 with her.  If she is with a group she acts very professional, but she is anything but when she is speaking with you out of the eye of everyone else.  This place has several guiding principals posted around the hospital and as your screen saver, but they do not actually live them.  If you are on their good side they let you slide on a lot of things; however, if you are not they call you on every little thing.  I would not wish this place on anyone!!

pros: At SAMC I felt like I made a decent salary. The health benefits were okay as well. However the cafeteria food was the best part of working there.
cons: Be prepared to feel like you're in high school again with the internal politics and those who  will point the finger in order to save themselves. Also, don't make the mistake of thinking that your boss has your back - even if that is what they tell you.

pros: The company really values good employees, they try to offer them incentives to keep them happy. The organization is a great place to work, and once you are in you will have a good job for awhile.
cons: They seem to make employees take a lot of metrics but  do not follow up on what the results were, or what they will do with the results, so people dislike taking surveys.

pros: Easy for the pay, good benefits,
cons: Don't give equal opportunities to all employees, have favorites, some work harder than others but the pay raise I'd the same, when the minimum wage went up they didn't go up with it just because we were making a few cents over the minimum meaning they technically pay more

pros: Good experience and great place to learn, especially for nursing students
cons:
Nurses in certain departments do not help their aides as much as they should; high numbers of patients assigned to each aide
Pay was low and never received raises or proper reviews from management

pros:
Co-workers were awesome, and made the job bearable 
A lot of opportunities for extra hours 
pay is really good especially if you work over night
cons:
Always short staffed so you're expected to do double the work in the same amount of time
Never recognized for working hard
Equipment is old and does not always work

pros: Wonderful people and teamwork in the ED. Techs, RNs, and docs all have great relationships; I truly enjoy coming to work every night.
cons: Older equipment that glitches often, and half of our WOWs are practically broken. Newer RNs and techs hired are required to work 7 shifts (84hr)/2 week pay period instead of the normal 6 shifts/pay period.

job_title: Hospitalist-internal Medicine Nurse Practitioner in Fresno, CA
pros: Physicians in this group value the Nurse Practitioners. Schedule was great as it was 7 on and 7 off. Patient load was fair.
cons: This is a level II hospital without the resources of level I so working here was an adjustment. Specialists were difficult to get a hold of as all specialties are contracted and not on sight.

review_title: Great place for a long term career!
job_title: Director Patient Access in Fresno, CA
pros: Employees understand and live the Mission. Physicians and employees provide outstanding care to the Community. Co-workers feel like family.... very caring environment! Great place for a long term career.
cons: Advancement can be slow but worth the wait.

review_title: Pay is great, staffing ratios are unsafe.
job_title: Clinical Nurse III in Fresno, CA
pros: Pay, self-scheduling, opportunities to pick up overtime, great work family.
cons: Management always tries to downstaff to stay out of the red. We have no CNAs in OB and our staffing ratios are so unsafe.

pros: Flexible schedule,  helping patients was rewarding.  Mission statement was followed and patient care is a plus.
cons: Advancement was hard unless you knew people.  Under staffed, over worked and under paid.

review_title: Saint Agnes MEDICAL Foundation is not apart of Saint Agnes Medical Center (hospital).
pros: Saint Agnes MEDICAL Foundation was founded in 2013 and is growing. Physicians, surgeons  and staff are nice and welcoming.
cons: This company cares about numbers and not really about employees. Human resource is not helpful and uncaring in their practice.

review_title: Working for Saint Agnes...always understaffed and over worked
pros: flexible schedule, and great cafeteria food
cons: always understaffed, overworked, and underpaid.

pros: Faith based, great people to work with, leadership support
cons: Not unique to Saint Agnes, but leadership can be be pro-active instead of reactive to challenges that exist at the bedside

pros: Helping patients with daily activities is very rewarding.
cons: Management lacks an objective/unbiased view of employees in the workplace.
